text: What is Council and how do I use it?

choices.text: Council is an app that will put pictures of beings (people and animals, usually) next to text that you write.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 302 of "Annual report of the Fruit Growers' Association of Ontario, 1896" (1897)

choices.text: You write out your "problem" (or topic) and "choices" (or responses) that go with it. Then, you send it before a council!Â The council is just images of beings from various public domain image sources, like The British Library and the Library of Congress.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 265 of "General physiology of muscles and nerves" (1881)

choices.text: Each choice is presented by a different council member. It's like when NPCs in a video game like Baldur's Gate II or King of Dragon Pass all pipe up with advice for you!
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 233 of "Webster's practical dictionary; a practical dictionary of the English language giving the correct spelling, pronunciation and definitions of words based on the unabridged dictionary of Noah Webster .." (1910)

choices.text: You can use to talk through things with yourself. Sometimes, just reading your choices back to yourself helps with thinking about a situation. In programming, this is sometimes called "rubber duck debugging" because you can gain insight into a problem by literally explaining your situation to a rubber duck.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 133 of "Sermons by Rev. Sam. P. Jones : as stenographically reported, and delivered in St. Louis, Cincinnati, Chicago, Baltimore, Atlanta, Nashville, Waco and other cities : with a history of his life, by Theodore M. Smith : with sermons b

choices.text: However, it can also apply to questions like "What should I make for dinner?" to "Should I interview for this job?" It's also good for exploring ideas that don't have a single answer like "Who is the best cat?"
Or you can use it to explain things, like this "problem" is doing! Or just put pictures next to pieces of text. It's not unlike zombo.com, in that sense.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 103 of "Zoological Society bulletin" (1901)

choices.text: To view all of your problems, you can click on "All Problems" at the bottom of every view. To add a new problem, you can click "Add new problem" at the bottom of the All Problems view.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 27 of "Profit and pleasure in goat-keeping; a practical conservative treatise presenting in concrete form the advantages of the modern milch goat, the various breeds, their care and management" (1915)

choices.text: In the editing view, click on the Problem text to edit it, then click outside of it to complete editing. (Later on, you'll be able to hit Cmd+Enter to complete.) Click "Add choice" to add a new choice, then click on the choice to edit it. Finally, you can view it with a council by click "Send before a council"!
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 76 of "Christian faith in an age of science" (1903)

choices.text: In the council view, you can click "Change council" to get a new council if you'd like your stuff presented to you by a fresh council. This may be the funnest part of the app.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 542 of "Transactions of the American Philosophical Society .." (1771)

choices.text: Your problems are all kept locally in your browser. They are not shared anywhere else.
choices.imageTitle: Image from page 534 of "Transactions of the American Philosophical Society .." (1771)

choices.text: Have fun and enjoy your councils! Email jimkang@gmail.com or tweet @deathmtn if you have questions.
